titleStmt.title: Ultramicro-trauma in the endometrial-myometrial junctional zone and pale cell migration in adenomyosis

analytic.title: Ultramicro-trauma in the endometrial-myometrial junctional zone and pale cell migration in adenomyosis

biblStruct.note: Received May 20, 2015; revised and accepted September 1, 2015;

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Objective: To determine if ultrastructural tissue trauma occurs in the junctional zone in uteri in adenomyosis.
Design: A case-control experimental study.
Setting: Endometriosis research center.
Patient(s): Twelve uteri with adenomyosis, and 9 uteri without adenomyosis, were gained during laparoscopy-assisted vaginal hysterectomy.

Intervention(s): Transmission electron microscopic study of the junctional zone, as well as immunohistochemical staining for epithelial cadherin, and van Gieson staining and immunofluorescence for CD45 and CD68.
Main Outcome Measure(s): Analysis of the electron microscopy photos and the immunoreactive scores of the staining.
Result(s): The inner myometrial muscle fibers were diversely arranged in adenomyosis; they were parallel to the basal endometrial glands in nonadenomyosis.

Nuclear membrane infolding of the basal glandular epithelium and the disruption of the interface between basal endometrium and inner myometrium in adenomyosis (but not in nonadenomyosis) were evident.
Intraepithelial pale cells were seen in the basal endometrial glands in both groups, but they lacked CD45 and CD68 expression.
They were seen actively migrating into the stroma in adenomyosis only.
Conclusion(s): The myofiber disarray in the inner myometrium, and the nuclear membrane irregularities in adenomyosis, are evidence for ultramicro-trauma in adenomyosis.
The migrating nonleukocytic pale cells may be involved in pathogenesis of adenomyosis.
(Fertil Steril Ò 2015;104:1475-83.
Ó2015 by American Society for Reproductive Medicine.
denomyosis is a disease defined by microscopic ectopic endometrial glands and stroma cells deep in the myometrium, surrounded by hypertrophic and hy-perplastic smooth muscle cells.
Patients who have this disease usually have menorrhagia and/or metrorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, pelvic pain, and dyspareunia (1).
Over the years, the real incidence of adenomyosis-uteri has been underestimated.

In the past decade, better resolution of transvaginal ultrasonography (TVUS) and widespread usage of MRIs have demonstrated a high prevalence of adenomyosis (as high as 91%) in patients who have endometriosis, particularly in patients with infertility (2).
The high prevalence may draw attention to a possible involvement of adenomyosis in the pathogenesis of adenomyosis and endometriosis-associated infertility.
Three zones can be identified on uterine T2 MRIs; the high-signal intensity endometrium, the low-signal intensity inner myometrium, and the intermediate-signal intensity outer myometrium (3).
The junctional zone between the basal endometrium and the inner myometrium became an area of interest for further study.

Although gravidity is clearly associated with adenomyosis (4,5), infertile patients diagnosed with adenomyosis showed lower implantation, clinical pregnancy, and ongoing pregnancy rates with an increased miscarriage rate compared with nonadenomyosis (6).

A thick myometrium >25 mm, diagnosed by TVUS in patients undergoing in vitro fertilization embryo transfer (IVF-ET), is correlated with a doubled rate for implantation failure, and with a 4fold increase in abortion rate (7).
Altogether, adenomyosis seems to be the most important factor for the outcome of IVF in patients who have endometriosis (8).
As long as the pathogenesis of adenomyosis remains unclear, innovative therapeutic options will be lacking.
Adenomyotic uteri in women of childbearing age exhibit hyperperistalsis, diagnosed by uterine radioscintigraphy (9).

Hyperperistaltic-induced microscopic tissue injury at the endometrial-myometrial junctional zone (EMJZ) has been speculated to facilitate the translocation of the basal endometrium into the myometrium.
This process might be eased by the hyperperistalsis-induced microscopic myometrial defects and the natural lack of an intervening submucosal layer (3).
The translocated basal endometrium implants itself deeply in the myometrium and develops into adenomyotic lesions.

This tissue injury might stimulate a process of tissue repair in which estrogen is locally produced in the adenomyotic lesions in a paracrine fashion, which in turn stimulates the oxytocin receptors on the myometrial smooth muscle fibers, causing more hyperperistalsis.
Subsequently, more tissue injury occurs, and a vicious cycle is established.
Iatrogenic trauma to the EMJZ (e.g., endometrial curettage, cesarean section, or myomectomy) may initiate the cycle as well (10).
The objective of our study was to focus on the EMJZ in adenomyosis, and search for any ultrastructural evidence of tissue injury that may occur in this zone.
The study was approved by the local institutional review board at the Charit e University of Medicine, Berlin, Germany (EA4/071/07), and all participants gave written consent.
All relevant clinical data relating to the patients were documented.
The uteri of 12 premenopausal patients, diagnosed with adenomyosis, were assigned to the adenomyosis group.
The clinical diagnosis was based either solely on TVUS or on TVUS in combination with MRI.
The intact uterus was removed during a laparoscopy-assisted vaginal hysterectomy.
Only uteri with histopathologically proven adenomyosis were included.
As a control group, 9 uteri from premenopausal patients were included and were histopathologically proven to be free of adenomyosis (Table 1).

Within 10 minutes of uterus removal, wedge-shape biopsies (12 Â 5 Â 10 mm) were obtained from the anterior and posterior walls, and the fundus of the uterus, at the intersection of 2 lines: the longitudinal midline of the uterus with the line at the level of the entrance of the fallopian tubes into the uterus.

One group of specimens was immediately fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde for paraffin-embedded sections, for subsequent light microscopic examination; the second group was fixed in Karnovsky fixative (7.5% glutaraldehyde and 3% paraformaldehyde) for transmission electron microscopy (TEM).
Both groups were fixed at 4 C for at least 24 hours.
This stain was used to evaluate the collagen fibers in the EMJZ.
Slides with paraffin-embedded sections were deparaffinized and rehydrated, as previously described (11), followed by transfer to an autostainer (Leica XL).

Slides were stained with resorcinol for 12 minutes, and immersed in Weigert's hematoxylin (Sigma-Aldrich) for 13 minutes, rinsed with distilled water, and stained with van Gieson solution for 8 minutes.
The paraffin-embedded slides were deparaffinized and rehydrated, as described previously (11).
Antigen retrieval in a citrate buffer solution (pH ¼ 6) for 20 minutes was followed by cooling for 20 minutes.
At room temperature, the background was blocked by fetal calf serum (FCS) and Avidin and Biotin Blocking Kit (Vector Laboratories) for 30 (FCS), 10 (Avidin), and 10 (Biotin) minutes, respectively.

Incubation for 1 hour at room temperature with a mouse monoclonal anti-epithelial (E)-cadherin-specific antibody (67A4, 1:50 diluted in Dako REAL antibody diluent; Dako) was followed by incubation with the rabbit anti-mouse secondary antibody for 40 minutes (IgG, 1:400; Jackson Immu-noResearch Laboratory).
A Streptavidin Alkaline Phosphatase Conjugate Kit (1:400; Roche) was used for 40 minutes, followed by a Fast Red substrate (Thermo Scientific) for 20 minutes.
Counterstaining with Mayer's hemalum solution (Merck) for 40 seconds followed.
The basal endometrial glands were examined under a light microscope (Axiophot Microscope; Carl Zeiss MicroImaging GmbH) in the whole field of the specimen, and an average was calculated.
In small-sized specimens, at least 4 different, randomly chosen visual fields on each slide, using magnification Â200, were considered.
The light microscopic examination was done by the first observer and confirmed by a second one, and both were blinded to patients' data.
Quantitative assessment regarding the percentage of positively stained, basal endometrial glands in each visual field ranged from 0% to 100%.
The qualitative assessment relied on the intensity of the staining, scored as follows: 0 ¼ no stain; 1 ¼ mild intensity; 2 ¼ moderate intensity; and 3 ¼ strong (intense) staining (11,12).

The average was calculated, and the final immunereactive score was calculated by multiplying the average qualitative score by the average quantitative score, with the lowest possible score being zero, and the highest 300.
Photographs were taken using a Canon PowerShot G5 camera (Canon, model number Pc1049) at various magnifications (Â10, Â20, Â40, or Â100 lenses) and edited using Adobe Photoshop (Adobe Systems, Inc).

div.head: Specimen Preparation for Electron Microscopy Examination

p.s: Specimens were fixed in Karnovsky solution (7.5% glutaraldehyde and 3% paraformaldehyde in phosphate buffered saline), washed in 0.1 M cacodylate buffer (cacodylic acid sodium salt trihydrate; Carl Roth), incubated in 1% osmium tetroxide (Chempur) for 120 minutes, dehydrated in a descending series of ethanol, and washed in the intermedium propylene oxide (1,2 Epoxypropan; VWR).

Specimens were subsequently embedded in a mixture of agar 100 (epoxy resin); DDSA (dodecenyl succinic anhydride; softener); MNA (methyl nadic anhydride; hardener); and DMP (dimethylaminoethyl phenol-30; catalyst) (all: Agar Scientific).
Polymerization was done at 45 C and 55 C each for 24 hours.
Semi-and ultrathin sections were cut using an ultramicrotome Reichert Ultracut S (Leica Microsystems).
Semi-thin sections (0.5 mm) were stained with modified Richardson solution (13).

Embedding was done in epoxy resins for ultrathin sectioning in electron microscopy for 45 seconds on an electric hot plate adjusted to 80 C. Sections were checked under a light microscope Olympus CX 21 (Olympus) to ensure the presence of the junctional zone.
Ultrathin (80-nm) sections were mounted on nickel grids (Agar Scientific) and examined with a transmission electron microscope (Zeiss EM 900; Carl Zeiss).
The anterior and posterior walls and the fundus of every patient were examined, and photos were taken and edited using Adobe Photoshop.

div.head: Immunofluorescence Staining for CD45 and CD68

p.s: The 4-mm-thick paraffin slides were deparaffinized and rehydrated as usual (11).
Antigen retrieval in citrate buffer (pH ¼ 6) for 20 minutes was followed by cooling for 20 minutes.

Blocking with fetal calf serum (FCS) for 20 minutes was followed by incubation with the primary antibody of CD45 (ab10559; Rabbit polyclonal IgG; Abcam) and CD68 (Ab-3 [clone:KP1]; Mouse monoclonal IgG1; Dianova) for 60 minutes at room temperature was followed by 1-hour incubation with the suitable secondary antibody, away from light.
The slides were covered with DAPI Fluoromount-G (South-ernBiotech) and examined under the microscope (Axiophot).
All statistical analyses were performed using GraphPad Prism 4 (GraphPad Software).
Student's t test and c 2 analysis were used.
All statistical tests were 2-sided.
The ages in both groups were matched and showed a nonsignificant difference, with the mean age being 43 years.
No significant difference was found in the gravidity or parity between the 2 groups.

div.head: Inner Myometrial Smooth Muscle Cell Orientation

p.s: Van Gieson stain (BioGenex) visualizes the orientation of the inner myometrial smooth muscle fibers.

In 5 patients of the nonadenomyosis group (55.6%), the endometrialmyometrial interface appeared regular and uninterrupted, and the smooth muscle fibers in the inner myometrium were parallel to the basal endometrial glands (Fig. 1A).
The outer myometrial smooth muscle cells were arranged in bundles in various orientations.

In the adenomyosis group, all patients (12 of 12) showed a disruption of the endometrialmyometrial interface at different locations with the basal endometrial glands seen dipping down into the inner myometrium, surrounded by collagen fibers (Fig. 1B).

The smooth muscle fibers located in the inner myometrium lost their parallel arrangement to the basal endometrial glands in all patients who had adenomyosis (compared with only 4 patients (44.4%) in the nonadenomyosis group).
Most of these smooth muscle bundles were obliquely arranged, some even perpendicular to the basal endometrium (Fig. 1C), mimicking the orientation of the outer myometrium.

div.head: Ultrastructural Changes in the Endometrial-Myometrial Junctional Zone

p.s: The ultrastructure of the EMJZ was analyzed, and changes in the basal endometrial, epithelial, and stromal cells, in addition to the myocytes and pale cells, were studied.
In the nonadenomyosis group, the interface between the stromal cells of the basal endometrium and the myocytes of the inner myometrium appeared to be regular and continuous (Fig. 2A).
By contrast, the endometrial-myometrial interface of the uteri of the adenomyosis group was interrupted.
Smooth muscle cells could be seen surrounding some basal endometrial glands, intermingling with the endometrial stromal cells.

In the nonadenomyosis group, the glandular epithelial cells had euchromatic nuclei with smooth and regular nuclear membranes in 8 (88.9%) patients, and an even distribution of the peripheral chromatin (Fig. 2B).
In all patients, the cytoplasm was rich in ribosomes and mitochondria.
Multiple desmosomes could be identified between their lateral cell borders (Fig. 2C).
In addition, the basal membranes of the endometrial glands were intact and completely surrounded by endometrial stromal cells.
In the nonadenomyosis group, the endometrial stromal cells had regular and relatively large nuclei with peripheral, evenly distributed chromatin.
The myocytes in the inner myometrium were arranged parallel to one another (Fig. 2D).
In the group with adenomyosis, the epithelial cells of the basal endometrial glands had euchromatic nuclei with peripherally arranged chromatin.
However, the nuclear membranes had multiple infolding and grooving in 8 (66.7%) patients (Fig. 2E); the desmosomes could be seen in all patients in the group (Fig. 2F).
The myocytes in the inner myometrium were seen to be diversely arranged (Fig. 2G).
Another cell population was seen next to the junctional zone in one adenomyosis patient.
Multiple heterogeneously electron-dense vesicles of various sizes replaced their nuclei Hence, we refer to them as ''vesiculated cells'' (Fig. 2H).
In both groups, tight junctions could be seen clearly on the upper lateral borders of the epithelial cells (Fig. 2I).

Another cell population found in 20 of the 21 (95%) patients (9 without and 11 with adenomyosis), was characterized by heterochromatic nuclei and mitochondrial and ribosomal abundance in the cytoplasm.
Their cytoplasm ap-peared more electro-lucent than that of the surrounding glandular epithelial cells; hence they are called ''pale cells'' (Fig. 2J).

Pale cells were located in the basal endometrial glands in both groups, in between the glandular epithelial cells; they were eccentrically located in most included patients (20 of 21), away from the gland lumen and in close contact with the basement membrane of the glands (Fig. 2K).
They appeared to be concentrically located and in close proximity to the gland lumen in only 3 patients (2 with and 1 without adenomyosis; Fig. 2L).
All pale cells were found to lack desmosomes in all patients (Fig. 2M).

In addition, the pale cells appeared to be located in a compartment enclosed by the neighboring glandular epithelial cells, with well-defined cellular interdigitations interposing between the pale cell above and the basement membrane below.
A thin channel could be seen between those cellular interdigitations of the glandular cells, running from the compartment occupied by the pale cell to the endometrial stromal compartment (Fig. 2N).
In the group with adenomyosis (9 of 12; 75%) and in the nonadenomyosis group (6 of 9; 66.7%), these cellular interdigitations became less complex, with fewer interdigitations in some locations.
The difference between the 2 groups was statistically significant (P¼ .0001).
Additionally, only a narrow cellular protrusion could be seen interposed between the pale cells and the basement membrane below (Fig. 2O).
The pale-cell borders were seen to be partially detached from the surrounding epithelial cell borders in 7 of 12 (58.3%)
and 5 of 9 (55.6%) in the adenomyosis and nonadenomyosis groups, respectively (Fig. 2P).
They were completely detached in 2 of 12 (16.7%)
patients of the adenomyosis group, but not in the nonadenomyosis group (Supplemental Table 1, available online).

In the basement membrane of the basal endometrial glands, multiple microruptures extending through the lamina rara and lamina densa were evident in 3 of 12 (25%) of the adenomyosis group, which was significantly different from the nonadenomyosis group (P¼ .0003).
Cellular buds (pseudopods) of the pale cells protruded through those microruptures in 2 of 12 (16.7%) of the adenomyosis group, but were lacking in the nonadenomyosis group (Fig. 2Q).

Further, the pale-cell cytoplasm was seen to be almost translocated through a microrupture of the basement membrane into the surrounding stroma in 2 of 12 (16.7%) of the adenomyosis group, but not in the nonadenomyosis group (Supplemental Table 2, available online).
Cellular organelles were seen not only in the translocated part of the pale cell but also at the point of basal membrane microrupture.
In nonadenomyosis patients, no total detachment, microruptures of the basement membrane, pseudopods, or cytoplasmic translocation could be detected (Fig. 2R).

The pale cells in the endometrial glands did not show any positive IF-staining in the basal endometrial glands in our patients (Fig. 3A and 3B), excluding the possibility of their being leukocytes or macrophages (Fig. 3A-3F).
To investigate the cell-cell contact between the epithelial cells in the basal endometrial glands, we studied the immune expression of the E-cadherin on the basal glandular epithelial cells.
No statistically significant difference was found between the 2 groups (P>.05) (Fig. 3G and H).
No difference was found among the anterior, posterior, and fundus region of the uterus from TEM, van Gieson staining, or E-cadherin immunolabeling.
The present study of the ultrastructure of the basal endometrium in uteri of patients who had adenomyosis revealed changes in the EMJZ, in comparison with nonadenomyosis.
Evidence could be seen of microscopic tissue injury at the EMJZ, as well as abnormal tissue healing.

We described the location and ultrastructure of a cell population in the EMJZ, the so-called pale cells, and their apparent ability to actively migrate into the surrounding stroma in patients with adenomyosis.
Examination was conducted of the areas normally subjected to the maximal shearing stress induced by uterine peristalsis, namely the fundo-cornual raphe (9,10).

div.head: Microscopic Tissue Injury at the Endometrial Junctional Zone

p.s: Histopathologic evidence of fissuring at the endometrialmyometrial interface in adenomyosis patients (11) as well as in endometriosis patients (9) has previously been reported, correlating with the observed dipping of the basal endometrial glands into the inner myometrium.

Transmission electron microscopy revealed that the myocytes appeared to be abnormally arranged around the basal endometrial glands in adenomyosis, with complete loss of the regular interface to the glands and their stroma.
To our knowledge, this is the first time TEM has been used to show the regular (nonadenomyosis) as well as irregular (adenomyosis) interfaces between the stromal cells and the inner myometrial cells.
Fibroids are known to disrupt the EMJZ (14), which may explain why the inner myometrium was parallel to the basal endometrium in only 42.9% of nonadenomyosis patients.
The loss of parallelism of the inner myometrial fibers in adenomyosis mimics the myofiber disarray noted at the site of a cesarean section or myomectomy scar in the course of tissue healing.
This disarray can lead to suboptimal smooth muscle contraction and muscular hypertrophy (15).
Experimentally induced adenomyosis in mice has produced thicker interwoven inner myometrium (16)(17)(18).
These findings provide better understanding of dysperistalsis in adenomyosis uteri, which might affect the upward transport of sperm, and hence compromise patients' fertility.

The electron microscopic photos added much evidence of microscopic tissue injury at the EMJZ, as the nuclear membranes of the epithelial cells in the basal endometrial glands of adenomyosis uteri were irregular, with infoldings and grooves.

We believe either of these possibilities are caused by the adenomyosis-induced hyperperistalsis, but they may reflect abnormal cellular behavior in favor of invasion, as seen in well-differentiated endometrial adenocarcinoma (19).
A similar irregularity has been seen in ovarian endometriomas (20).

The desmosomes observed using TEM, as well as the nonsignificant E-cadherin immune-expression between the 2 groups, could indicate that translocation of fragments of the basal endometrium into the myometrium is not a step in adenomyosis pathogenesis.
The same result was seen in a previous study of E-cadherin (21).
The precise role of the ''vesiculated'' cells is unknown.
They could be apoptotic or necrotic cells, or a degenerating form of glandular epithelial cells.
The finding (20) of apoptosis in ectopic endometrium of adenomyosis lesions and ovarian endometriomas, using TEM, supports our speculation.

div.head: Pale Cells Seem to Be Mobile

p.s: For the first time, and based on TEM, we were able to describe a cell population found among the epithelial cells of the basal glands at the EMJZ in both groups.
Their position varied between being eccentric and concentric.
Their cytoplasm appeared electro-lucent and could resemble the chromophobe reserve cells in the anterior pituitary gland (22).
The pale cells have been observed before in the pelvic peritoneal endometriotic lesions, irrespective of the cycle day (23) (Supplemental Fig. 1, available online).
Pale cells in the basal endometrium showed a unique feature: mobility.
They lack the desmosomal connection with the surroundings; the same was seen in peritoneal endometrium (23).

Furthermore, E-cadherin-negative epithelial cells were seen among E-cadherin-positive glandular epithelium, in both endometriotic lesions and their eutopic endometrium, more frequently than in normal eutopic endometrium (24).
The loss of E-cadherin is characteristic of acquisition of invasiveness, as E-cadherin-negative cells from peritoneal endometrium are uniquely invasive of the collagen gel (25).
The basement membrane of the basal endometrial glands in adenomyosis showed multiple ultramicroruptures at various locations.

As these microperforations of the basement membrane could not be seen with the ordinary light microscope, but only with TEM, we prefer to use the term ''ultramicrorupture,'' for a more precise description.

Tortuosity of the basement membrane has been previously described in the ectopic endometrium of adenomyosis and ovarian endometriomas (20); it has been observed to be disrupted in atypical endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial carcinoma (26).

The observed pseudopods of the pale cells suggest an active migration process that resembles the migration process of the leukocytes from the bloodstream to the extracellular tissue, in response to trauma through the basement membrane (27).
But the pale cells could be excluded as being neither macrophage nor leukocyte.

div.head: The Pathogenesis of Adenomyosis: New Insight

p.s: To date, retrograde menstrual blood was believed to contain basal endometrial fragments, with a stem cell-like character, that could translocate into the myometrium to develop into adenomyosis (28).

Our results provide novel insight into the pathogenesis of adenomyosis: The pale cells-rather than the whole basal endometrial gland-may migrate (under certain conditions) into the stroma of the basal endometrium and subsequently into the myometrium.
Pale cells probably migrate actively, rather than being passively translocated through the basement membrane of the basal endometrial glands.

Their migration, which could be staged, may be facilitated by the high concentration of matrix metalloproteinase (MMP) (especially types 2 and 9) in the uterine fluid (lavage) (29) and the higher expression level of the stromal cells (30) from adenomyosis uteri.

The basement membrane of the endometrial basal glands could play a protective role, one normally played by the submucosal layer in other organs (e.g., the intestine), and maintain the glands' structural integrity.

Loss of the desmosomal junctions is considered to be the first step in epithelialmesenchymal transformation (EMT) to build up adenomyotic foci (31), mediated by the high level of transforming growth factor beta 1 in the uterine lavage from adenomyosis uteri (29).

div.head: New Insight Into a Common Pathogenesis of Endometriosis and Adenomyosis

p.s: Based on the previous findings, we could support the assumption of the common pathogenesis of endometriosis and adenomyosis depending on the following observations:
1. Nuclear membrane irregularities are observed in both endometrial lesions and the basal endometrium of adenomyosis.
2. The ultrastrucutral abnormality of the basement membrane in the ectopic endometrium of adenomyosis, endometriomas, and in the basal endometrial glands of adenomyosis.
3. The pale cells could be seen in the basal endometrium and in the peritoneal endometrial lesions, reflecting their bidirectional migration ability (Fig. 3I).
4. The pale cells do lack desmosomes correlating to those Ecadherin-negative epithelial cells in endometrial lesions. 5.

The invasive character of the E-cadherin-negative epithelial cells in endometriosis could be correlated to the migration ability of the pale cells into the stroma in adenomyosis described in our study (Supplemental Fig. 1).
Pale cells may be endometrial stem cell-like cells of high metabolic activity, capable of active migration, given that they are located in the basal endometrium (32) in both groups.
Further characterization of pale cells using specific stem-cell markers is needed.
Frequency of various migration steps of the pale cells in the nonadenomyosis group.

The ultrastructure of a pale cell.
The cytoplasm is rich in mitochondria (arrow) with a euchromatic chromatin.
The pale cells are seen migrating into the stroma and lying directly on the basement membrane of the endometrial glands (stars).
